posts.name: Judah
posts.cooked: Hi, I’ve noticed that in every differential swerve module I’ve seen, the motors are always on opposite sides of the module. Why are they always opposite, and what would happen if the two motors were placed next to each other? I feel that would reduce the overall size of the module as the module wouldn’t be a perfect circle, but more of a circle with a little nub coming out of one side for the motors. Another reason why this would be beneficial (The reason I originally thought this question) is because it would allow the wheels to be spaced at least an extra inch outwards, increasing overall stability.

posts.name: Jared
posts.cooked: What specific diffy swerves are you looking at that use such a configuration? The only ones I can think of are the two-module FTC bots, but that’s (ironically) for the purpose of space efficiency

posts.name: Judah
posts.cooked:
I’m going to be designing my own modules for a personal project due to size limitations. All of the modules I’ve seen so far look like this in terms of their input motor placements: dif swerve 1445×740 197 KB

dif swerve 1445×740 197 KB

dif swerve 1445×740 197 KB

posts.name: Judah
posts.cooked: I’m just wondering if I could move one of the inputs so that it’s right next to the other input. If I do that, both inputs can be on the corner that is closest to the center of the bot, which would increase the distance between the wheel and center of the bot.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
Not sure if this is what you are asking but I believe it is mostly due to to packaging and not requiring mirrored modules for the opposite side. You can see on our test chassis for 88’s Dify swerves we had the motors both in one side. PXL_20220520_011123567.PORTRAIT 1920×2560 392 KB

PXL_20220520_011123567.PORTRAIT 1920×2560 392 KB

PXL_20220520_011123567.PORTRAIT 1920×2560 392 KB

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Yeah moving the small gears around the big gear until they’re next to each other shouldn’t do anything bad. They’re applying the same torques either way. There might be a small unbalanced force on the large turntable bearings but it should be very minor compared to other loads.

posts.name: Jared
posts.cooked: I can’t see any issues with doing that.

posts.name: Judah
posts.cooked: I can’t see the motors, but what you’re saying about packaging makes sense. If there isn’t a reason to not have them mirrored, then I guess it’s better to just leave them be for most cases.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: The motors went on the long sides of each module, they were 8 falcons so we took them off after we did testing with them during the summer of 2021.
